Comment:
Find here is a game that illustrates a Caro-Kann Defense: Advance Variation (B12).

nota: This opening has been more and more played since 1990.

Caro-kann advance variation's stats:
White wins 40.0%
Black wins 27.3%
Draws 32.6%
c6 doesn't mean you abandon the center. You are even not late. It is like a call on whites cards and intentions.

There are some N variations of the Caro-Kann my knowledge of them are limited.

Also Tarrash responded (1889) e5 on d4 played by Amos Burn.

Caro-Kann Defense advance variation position
Blacks have options (Bf5/C5/F6!/etc.) even if there is an advanced e5.
This position gives me focus on e5 and d4. Once d5 is down whites are mostly done as I know that many players can not resist to play e5.

The first step to get ride of e5 is to attack strongly d4.
The game between V. Promyshlyanskiy vs Daniel Fridman during the LGA Premium Cup (09/08/2006) illustrates it.
